title: @Meddler Randuin's Omen reduces Anivia's Damage
body:
TLDR: {{item:3143}} reduces {{champion:34}}'s E damage

EDIT: Meddler: "Just heard back from Xypherous, apparently that's working as intended. Randuin's should be reducing any form of crit damage, not just auto attack crits (so anything that uses the crit combat text/symbol)."

------------------

I was at an end game stat screen and i noticed that {{champion:34}}  enhanced damage on her E is considered a "critical strike"

Then I went into a custom game with {{champion:16}}  and {{champion:34}}  to test out if {{item:3143}} reduced the damage dealt by the spells.

The results were that {{champion:16}} Q damage was not affected by {{item:3143}}, but {{champion:34}} e damage is reduced by a certain amount. Even though both instances of damage were labeled as "largest critical strike", why is this different? And is the damage reduction on {{champion:34}} intended?

------------------
Test methods. 
{{champion:16}}  was hit by {{champion:34}} E while slowed and non slowed, then the same process repeats with the {{champion:16}} equipping {{item:3143}}. 
The non slow damage instances in both cases were the same, showing the bonus armor and health does not affect the magic damage of {{champion:34}}'s E. 
However, the slowed damage were different with the {{item:3143}} reducing the damage from 271 magic damage to 258 magic damage on a level 7 {{champion:16}} with no defensive runes. 
Concluding that {{item:3143}} reduces {{champion:34}}'s E damage

-----------------
List of champions that uses crit symbol:

Not Tested: {{champion:79}} {{champion:40}} 

Reduced by Omen: {{champion:34}} {{champion:30}}

Not Reduced by omen: {{champion:16}}

Okay...but WHY is that intended?

Like, that's not a logical conclusion. 'Shit, that Anivia is doing a lot of damage. What should I do to stop her...hmm, BV obviously, maybe an Aegis...oh, and a giant armor item!'

Isn't that the reason you nerfed AP Trynd? Because he was buying AP but doing physical damage, so people were confused as to what to buy to build against him?

Even with the reduction to spell's flagged as crits Randuin's is still going to be a poor choice if you need survivability against a heavy magic damage dealer like Anivia. It will sometimes offer a small point of optimization if you're trying to decide between Randuin's and another Armor item to deal with a physical though if there's a champ like Anivia on the enemy team as well. As far as logical conclusions go the passive reduces damage from everything that gets displayed as a crit in game. I'd agree that results in interactions like this not being intuitive at first glance, there's some argument for an expanded tooltip as a result (versus the tradeoff of additional tooltip length of course). 

The main reasons we nerfed AP Trynd were that he was extremely overpowered and lacked counterplay. When Q healed for the same amount regardless of how much rage he had AP Trynd was able to heal through pretty much anything a single champion could do, while being mobile, killing towers quickly and wave clearing easily. There are other strong split pushers in the game still, AP Trynd was massively above them though when played well, and in a way other characters generally weren't able to interact with much.

You're going to make the tooltip read "if the damage dealt number is displayed in a slightly different way than normal, but is still not something you pay attention to, the damage is reduced"?

I dare you to pick a player at random and see if that decision makes any sense to them.

Charity demands that Randuins either ignores magic damage crits ***or*** that crit modifying/interacting items, runes, and masteries also work with Spell Crits.

But Randuin's doesn't say that it reduces damage against everything that is displayed as a crit; it's damage reduction against critical strikes. Her E does not critically strike, it just 'deals extra damage'.
Isn't that a critical strike? You're dealing more damage than you normally would?

AP Trynd was nerfed because he was obliterating waves and was nigh unkillable, accomplishing the obscene task of being even more PvE oriented than AD Trynd is. It had little to do with how good having mixed damage made him at killing people

Anyways, Randuins reducing Anivia's E damage is absurd and should be changed. You shouldn't be protected against Anivia for building armor. It almost makes it worse that it sounds like that they intended that interaction to be that way. 

There's also no reason for players to believe it works like that. This goes back to the "clarity" thing that was getting harped about a while ago. Anivias E text does not state "crits against slowed targets", nor does her E benefit from IEdge. Her E against slowed targets is NOT a critical strike, does not work like one, and should not be treated as one by Randuins.

Like building an MR item to survive the burst of an AD assassin Zed? This game's counters and interactions are not always intuitive, and that's not a bad thing ... but it should make **sense**. Right now, Anivia E is a critical strike in that Randuin's decreases the damage it deals, but is not a critical strike in that runes, masteries, and IE don't affect it (and no text anywhere explicitly calls it a critical strike, there's just an exclamation point and a little explosion to indicate that it *might* be one).

Speaking of Soraka and unintentional problems, Meddler... This particular one has been brought up many, many times before and has been ignored for the past 6+ months. Equinox works as intended, but not to its full potential. I was playing as Soraka, and literally 30 minutes ago, Skarner ultid Corki into our base through the gates. I dropped Equinox on top of Corki, with Corki being in the VERY center... As soon as Skarner's ulti expired, however, Corki immediately Valkyrie'd out of my Equinox into safety. This clearly isn't supposed to happen, but evidently Equinox isn't ticking or the game isn't checking for Equinox quickly enough.

This very problem can be reproduced with Hourglass especially. If you drop Equinox on top of a champion in stasis, they can immediately slip out of it i.e. Fizz's Trickster. Please don't ignore me and look into this problem! It's extremely frustrating! :(

I know why this happens. Not too long ago they made it so while in untargetable states (zhonya's/skarner ult/etc) you can queue up commands to cast immediately upon exiting that state. So obviously these commands are taking priority over Soraka's silence.

I agree this is something that needs to be fixed.
